title: Transurban backs stimulus calls
text:
Transurban chairman Lindsay Maxsted has backed the Reserve Bank's calls for more investment in new and existing infrastructure to boost the economy as he warned traffic growth on the company's tollroads was slowing.

"While we do not believe the Australian economy is approaching a recession short of any major global dislocation, its current sluggish state speaks to the need for an even greater injection in infrastructure investment to help stimulate growth," Mr Maxsted told Transurban's annual general meeting in Melbourne.

"We would support Reserve Bank governor Philip Lowe's call for a major investment program in both new infrastructure projects and maintenance of existing infrastructure to generate growth."

Mr Maxsted said slowing traffic on Transurban's tollroads was most evident in Sydney, where the annual rate of economic growth was its weakest since the global financial crisis.

"This further supports the need for greater infrastructure investment, particularly in the context of our growing population and with some infrastructure struggling to meet demand," he said.

Average daily traffic on Transurban's Sydney tollroads rose only 0.1 per cent in the September quarter, excluding the new M4 tollroad which opened in July, while Melbourne's traffic rose just 0.6 per cent.
